658/ [2005] During 2005 the return of all Wisconsin inmates placed in out-of-state private correctional facilities was completed. Expanded county jail contracting, additional capacity at an existing facility and the opening of two new facilities made this possible. The stabilization and/or decline in population may reflect a renewed emphasis on treatment (particularly AODA) with an expansion of prison beds available for Alternative to Revocation placements for offenders in the Community. Another contributing factor may have been an Earned Release Program for incarcerated offenders begun in 2004.

659/ [2005] [In this report, unlike previous years:] Both the custody and jurisdiction populations now include all 886 offenders admitted as Temporary Probation and Parole Placements. Previously these admissions had been excluded from the custody population count.

660/ [2006] At the end of CY 2006 there were an additional 646 offenders in the custody and 722 offenders in the jurisdictions populations compared to the end of CY 2005. Two admission categories accounted for most of this growth in both the male and female inmate populations: Extended Supervision violator only (+707: +646males and +60 females) and New Sentence, Extended Supervision Violator (+154: +142 males and +12 females). These admission categories reflect the increasing prevalence of Wisconsin offenders convicted under the State's new Truth-in-Sentencing law. There were only slight changes or a decline in the numbers for the remaining admission categories. A male/female difference was apparent in two admission categories. There were 80 more males present as Temporary Probation and Parole placements at the end of 2006 compared to 2005, while the number of female offenders in this category did not change. Female offenders in the Alternative to Prison program increased substantially over 2005 (19 vs. 5) while male offenders declined from 38 in 2005 to 29 at the end of 2006.

661/ [2006] [In this report, unlike previous years:] Both the custody and jurisdiction populations now include all offenders admitted as Temporary Probation and Parole Placements. Previously these admissions had been excluded from the custody population count.

662/ [2007,2008] At the end of CY 2007 there were an additional 255 offenders in the custody and 328 offenders in the jurisdictions populations compared to the end of CY 2006. These numbers represent continued growth but are substantially less than the numbers seen between CY2005 and CY2006. The change in numbers for males reflects a slower (or slowing) growth rate over the course of the recent year, while the growth rate for female offenders continues at a much higher rate.

663/ [2009] 28 prisoners (26 males and 2 females) were excluded from the jurisdiction population because they are not serving a Wisconsin sentence. 25 males and 2 females in escape status are not included in items 3-5 but are included in jurisdiction population (Wisconsin does not code escapes as releases and returns from the escape as admissions).

664/ [2009] At the end of CY 2009 there were an additional 331 more offenders in the custody population but 226 fewer offenders in the jurisdictions populations compared to the end of CY 2008. The population decline may reflect the initiation of earned release policies in the new state budget signed in the fiscal year that began in July 2009. The decline in admissions reflects the impact of Truth-in-Sentencing.
